texts.shortText: Body elongate and cylindrical in cross-section. Colour pale, speckled with brown, second pair of antennae greatly enlarged and thickened in males and with a curved tooth on underside of 4th segment. First pair of limbs (gnathopod 1) with a small claw, second pair very setose, but lacking claw. Last three abdominal segments (urosome segment 1–3) all fused.

Global: Originally from western North Atlantic, but has been spread by human activities to Europe, Australia, New Zealand, South America, South Africa and various other regions.

Local/Regional: Throughout region, especially in harbours, but also in natural habitats.

Tube dwelling species that can occur in densities of thousands per square meter. Thought to have been distributed from its native habitat in North America on the hulls of ships, or associated with oysters shipped for culture. First recorded in South Africa in 1915. Can form burrows in mud on soft substrata, or live attached to rocks, among benthic organisms such as mussels, or on pilings, buoys, ships hulls and other artificial structures.
Water is propelled through the tube by beating of the pleopods and food particles filtered out with the setose legs.

As with all amphipods, sexes are separate. The eggs are extruded into a marsupial chamber beneath the legs of females, where they are fertilized by the male and develop into fully formed young before being released.
The hugely enlarged second antennae of males with the ventral tooth on segment 4, and the fused abdominal segments 4–6, readily distinguish this species.

Branch, G, Griffiths, CL, Branch, M & Beckley, L (2016). Two Oceans: A Guide to the Marine Life of Southern Africa. (Fifth edition) Struik Nature, Cape Town. (p. 344).

Griffiths, CL (1976). Guide to the benthic marine amphipods of Southern Africa. Trustees of the South African Museum, Cape Town (p. 32).

Picker, M & Griffiths, CL (2011). Alien and Invasive animals: a South African perspective. Struik Nature, Cape Town (p. 163).
